abstract.title: Summary
abstract.p: Ciliopathies are genetic disorders caused by defects in the structure or function of the cilia and their related structures. Bardet-Biedl syndrome (BBS) is a complex ciliopathy with varied symptoms, probably due to altered membrane receptor signalling pathways. This study explores the role of BBS1 and BBS4 gene deficiencies in receptor trafficking and epithelial-mesenchymal transition (EMT) in retinal epithelial cells. Deficiencies in these genes, key components of the BBSome complex, led to shorter cilia and disrupted receptor endocytosis. BBS1 knockout (KO) cells showed delayed transferrin internalisation and increased recycling of TGFBR1, promoting EMT. On the contrary, BBS4 KO cells had higher receptor degradation but no affected recycling. These disruptions suggest that BBSome regulates both ciliary and nonciliary pathways. Increased EMT markers in BBS1 KO cells were associated with higher cell migration and reduced proliferation, highlighting the role in receptor trafficking and potential therapeutic targets for retinal degeneration in BBS.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Ciliopathies are a group of genetic disorders characterized by abnormalities in the structure or function of cilia and their associated centrosomes or basal bodies. These disorders often arise from defects in the primary cilium, a specialized, antenna-like organelle that extends from the surface of most vertebrate cells (Satir and Christensen, 2007). The primary cilium plays a crucial role in detecting and translating external environmental signals into intracellular responses, regulating a wide range of developmental signalling pathways, such as Hedgehog, Wnt, and TGF-β/BMP (Anvarian et al., 2019; Hilgendorf et al., 2024). These pathways are essential for proper cellular communication, tissue development, and organogenesis. When the function of the primary cilium is disrupted, it can lead to a variety of clinical manifestations, which include most tissues and organs of the body, underscoring the importance of cilia in maintaining normal cellular and developmental processes. (Reiter and Leroux, 2017; Mill et al., 2023).

Bardet-Biedl syndrome (BBS) is a multisystemic ciliopathy marked by retinal degeneration, obesity, polydactyly, intellectual disability, cryptorchidism, and renal abnormalities, with retinal disease being the most penetrant feature (Denniston et al., 2014; Forsythe et al., 2018). BBS is associated with mutations in genes encoding proteins predominantly localised to the primary cilium, centrosome, basal body, and transition zone. Notably, eight of these genes (BBS1, BBS2, BBS4, BBS5, BBS7, BBS8, BBS9, and BBS18) encode components of the BBSome, an octameric protein complex, which functions as cargo adaptor for the retrograde intraflagellar transport (IFT) machinery to promote exit of ubiquitinated receptors from the cilium (Wingfield et al., 2018; Mill et al., 2023). Consequently, mutations in BBS genes cause major changes in the ciliary membrane proteome to some extent associated with defective Hedgehog (HH) and G-protein-coupled receptor (GPCR) signalling (Anvarian et al., 2019; Mill et al., 2023). Specifically, previous research from our laboratory has demonstrated the involvement of the transforming growth factor β (TGF-β) pathway in ciliopathy development (Álvarez-Satta et al., 2021).

Previous studies have established a functional connection between endosomal recycling and the primary cilium. In many cell types, including retinal pigment epithelium (RPE) cells, the base of the primary cilium is situated within a specialized invagination of the plasma membrane known as the ciliary pocket (CiPo). This region is a hub for clathrin-mediated endocytosis (CME), facilitating the formation of early endosomes and driving endocytic recycling (Westlake et al., 2011; Benmerah, 2013; Clement et al., 2013). The close association between the CiPo and these endocytic processes highlights the crucial role of the ciliary pocket in regulating the trafficking of signalling molecules and receptors, thereby influencing ciliary function and downstream cellular signaling pathways such as in Hedgehog (Bhattacharyya et al., 2016) and TGF-β/BMP signalling (Clement et al., 2013; Mönnich et al., 2018). Additionally, functional connections between the BBSome and the recycling endosome factor RAB11 have been identified. ARL13B, another ciliary protein, is critical for endocytic recycling (Barral et al., 2012), underscoring the role of ciliary proteins in the recycling and transport of endosomal cargo. Deficiencies in receptor internalisation, such as Notch, leptin, and insulin receptors, have been documented in cell lines with BBSome dysfunction (Seo et al., 2009; Leitch et al., 2014; Starks et al., 2015; Guo et al., 2016).

The RPE is a layer of specialized, polarized cells between the choriocapillaris and the neural retina. This layer of cells is crucial for maintaining photoreceptor health by forming a blood-retina barrier, disposing of damaged photoreceptor segments, maintaining the retinoid cycle, and protecting against light-induced and oxidative stress (Strauss, 2005). Disruptions in these processes, particularly in protein recycling and maintenance of RPE cell polarity, can lead to dysfunction. Among these processes, autophagy and epithelial-mesenchymal transition (EMT) are particularly noteworthy. EMT in RPE cells can result in impaired tight junctions, accumulation of misfolded proteins, and dysregulation of key pathways, such as TGF-β, Wnt, and extracellular vesicle trafficking, which are also implicated in ciliopathies (Zhou et al., 2020).
This study aims to investigate the role of plasma membrane alterations in receptor endocytosis pathways that may contribute to the pathological phenotype observed in the retinas of BBS patients.

sec.title: Cell culture and treatment
sec.p: Human retinal pigment epithelial cells (hTERT RPE1, ATCC CRL-4000, female) and human embryonic kidney cells (293T, ATCC CRL-3216, female) were cultured in Dulbecco’s Modified Eagle Medium F-12 nutrient mix (DMEM/F-12) supplemented with 10% fetal bovine serum (FBS) and 1% penicillin/streptomycin (P/S), when appropriate. Hygromycin B (0.01 mg/ml) was added for RPE1 cells. Cultures were maintained at 37°C with 5% CO2 for up to one month. Cells were serum-depleted for 48 h before stimulation with TGF-β (2 ng/ml), EGF (20 ng/ml), or fluorescently labelled transferrin (20 ng/ml). Bafilomycin A1 (20 nM) was used as an autophagy inhibitor.

sec.title: CRISPR/Cas9 assay and edition validation
sec.p: RPE1 cells were edited using a lentivirus system according to the protocol described by other labs (Ran et al., 2013; Shalem et al., 2014), with some modifications. After lentiviral transduction, cells were selected with puromycin (50 μg/ml) for 5 days.

Surviving cells were expanded and isolated to obtain individual clones. The isolation was performed using Fluorescence-Activated Cell Sorting (FACS) with Hoechst (BD Bioscience) in the flow cytometer FACS ARIA III (BD Bioscience, San José, United States). Inhibition of gene expression was validated by qPCR in QuantStudio3 (Thermo Fisher Scientific). Primer information can be checked in Supplementary Tables 1 and 2. Those clones with a gene expression less than or equal to 11% were tested by western blot. Finally, those that did not present a band in the size corresponding to the BBS1 and BBS4 proteins were selected.

sec.title: RNA extraction and RT-PCR
sec.p: RPE1 cells were seeded in 6-well plates at a concentration of 1,5 × 105 by triplicate in DMEM/F-12 1% P/S and were incubated for 48 h for serum depletion. Then, cells were stimulated with rhTGF-β1 (2 ng/ml) for 30 mins. DMEM was removed and wells were washed twice with PBS. Cells were scraped in PBS and collected in 1.5 ml tubes. For the RNA extraction, the NYZ total RNA isolation kit (NYZtech) was used following the manufacturer’s protocol. This process was repeated with cells without stimulation. After RNA elution, the sample concentrations were measured with Nanodrop (Thermo Fisher Scientific). Next, 100 ng of RNA was retrotranscribed to cDNA using the NZY First-Strand cDNA Synthesis kit (NYZtech) following the manufacturer’s protocol.

sec.title: qPCR expression analysis
sec.p: qPCR was performed on samples prepared in 96-well plates using PowerUp SYBR Green Master Mix and QuantStudio3 (Thermo Fisher Scientific). Gene expression was normalised using the ΔΔCT method with ALAS1, YWHAZ, or B2M as housekeeping genes. Each sample was analysed in technical triplicates, for two biological replicates (clones 1 and 2). Primers can be found in Supplementary Table 3.

sec.title: Fluorescence imaging
sec.p: Cells were grown on glass coverslips in a 6-well plate. 48 h later, cells were treated as indicated. Coverslips were then fixed with 4 % ice-cold paraformaldehyde (PFA) in 20 mM HEPES pH 7.5 for 10 min. Cells were permeabilised in 0.1% Triton X-100 in PBS for 5 min at RT. Slides were then incubated in primary antibodies in blocking buffer (1% BSA in PBS) at 37°C for 2–3 h or overnight at 4°C, followed by incubation with Alexa-conjugated secondary antibodies (Invitrogen) for 1 h at room temperature. Finally, nuclei were stained with 1 μg/ml DAPI (Sigma) for 5 min at RT; then, coverslips were mounted on microscope slides with Prolong Diamond Anti-fade (Invitrogen).

Transferrin recycling was assayed by stimulating cells with 20 ng/ml Alexa 555-Transferrin (555-Tfn, Invitrogen) and then chasing with Tfn-free, serum-free media to allow recycling of the Tfn before fixing with 4 % PFA and staining for RAB11 and EEA1.

sec.title: Membrane biotinylation assay
sec.p: RPE1 cells were seeded in 100 mm dishes by triplicate in DMEM/F-12 1% P/S, 10% FBS. After that, DMEM was removed, and wells were washed twice with ice-cold PBS and labelled with 0.5 mg/ml biotin (EZ-Link sulfo-NHS-SS-biotin, Thermo Fisher Scientific) for 30 min at 4°C. Excess sulfo-NHS-SS-biotin was washed off with PBS and then quenched with 100 mM glycine for 15 min at 4°C. To isolate biotinylated proteins, cells were lysed in RIPA buffer with proteasome, protease and phosphatase inhibitors and then incubated overnight at 4°C with Streptavidin Sepharose High Performance (Cytiva). To load the same amount of protein to the beads, protein quantification was performed by Pierce™ BCA Protein Assay Kit (Thermo-Fisher Scientific) microplate assay (Bio-Rad). Beads were washed three times with RIPA and then once with RIPA supplemented with 300 mM NaCl final concentration, followed by two washes with PBS. Beads were then analysed by SDS−PAGE and Western blotting or prepared for mass spectrometer analysis.
RIPA composition: TrisHCl (pH 7.4) 50 mM, NaCl 150 mM, EDTA 5 mM, EGTA 1 mM, NP-40 alternative 1%, Na desoxycholate 0.5%, SDS 0.1%.

sec.title: Protein extraction for proteomic profiling
sec.p: For the plasma membrane proteomic profile, beads were resuspended in 100 μL 2 M urea, 100 mM Tris (pH 7,5), 1 mM DTT buffer, and 2 μg/mL trypsin and incubated at 37 °C 30 min in a shaker (1000 rpms). After that, the beads were spined at 8,000 rpm for 1 min at RT. The supernatant was kept in a new low protein biding microcentrifuge tube and incubated overnight at 37 °C. The next day, 5 μL of 10% TFA (trifluoroacetic acid) was added to stop the reaction. Samples were aliquoted and stored at −80°C or directly sent to the core facility for C18 purification before mass spec analysis.

sec.title: Mass spectrometry and bioinformatic analysis
sec.p: The desalted and lyophilized peptides were resuspended in 0.1% TFA and subjected to mass spectrometric analysis by reversed-phase nano–liquid chromatography-tandem mass spectrometry (LC-MS/MS). Mass spectrometry: 5 µl of the resuspended peptides were analyzed by reversed-phase nano–LC-MS/MS using a nano-Ultimate 3000 LC system and a Lumos Fusion mass spectrometer (Thermo Fisher Scientific). Flow rates were 400 nl/min. Peptides were loaded onto a self-packed analytical column (uChrom 1.6, 0.075 mm by 25 cm) using a 67-min gradient buffer A (2% acetonitrile, 0.5% acetic acid) and buffer B (80% acetonitrile, 0.5% acetic acid); 0 to 16 min: 2% buffer B, 16 to 56 min: 3 to 35% buffer B, 56 to 62 min: 99% buffer B; 62 to 67 min 2% buffer B. Full-scan spectra recording in the Orbitrap was in the range of m/z 350 to m/z 1,400 (resolution: 240,000; AGC: 7.5e5 ions). MS2 was performed in the ion trap, with an isolation window of 0.7, an AGC of 2e4, an HCD collision energy of 28, rapid scan rate, a scan range of 145 to 1450 m/z, 50-ms maximum injection time, and an overall cycle time of 1 s.

After PEAKS imputation, an in-house limma pipeline developed by Wasim Aftab (available at [https://github.com/wasimaftab?tab=repositories](https://github.com/wasimaftab?tab=repositories)) was used to log-transform and impute the provided data. The imputation process utilized a downshift of 3 and a width cutoff of 0.3. Differential expression analysis between the two groups was performed using the Empirical Bayes Statistics method within this pipeline. The Go Terms analysis was performed with the Clusterprofiler package (Yu et al., 2012), and results were visualized with the GOplot package (Walter et al., 2015).

sec.title: TGF-β activation assays with SDS-PAGE, Western Blotting, and quantification
sec.p: For TGF-β activation assays, RPE1 cells, both wild-type (WT) and knockout (KO) were plated in 6-well plates. The cells were initially incubated under two conditions: in DMEM without FBS and in DMEM supplemented with 1% P/S and 10% FBS. This incubation period lasted for 48 h. Following this, the TGF-β pathway was activated by adding recombinant human TGF-β1 (rhTGF-β1) ligand at a final concentration of 2 ng/ml to each well. The cells were stimulated for varying durations, specifically 0, 10, 30, 60, 90, and 120 min. After the designated stimulation period, the cells were washed three times with PBS to remove excess ligands. The cells were then harvested using a scraper and collected by centrifugation at 7,400 × g for 10 min at 4°C.

The resulting cell pellets were lysed on ice for 10 min in 200 μL of RIPA lysis buffer with inhibitors. The lysates were then centrifuged at 14,500 × g for 30 min at 4°C, and the supernatant was carefully collected into 1.5 ml low-binding tubes. The remaining pellet was discarded. Protein concentrations were determined using the Pierce™ BCA Protein Assay Kit (Thermo Fisher Scientific), and the samples were subsequently stored at −80°C until they were ready for further analysis.

For SDS-PAGE and Western blotting, 15 μg of total protein from each sample was prepared by mixing with 6.25 μL of Laemmli Buffer 4X (Bio-Rad), 1.25 μL β-mercaptoethanol (BME), and an appropriate volume of distilled water to achieve a final volume of 25 μL. These samples were then denatured by boiling at 95°C for 5 min. The denatured samples were loaded onto a Mini-PROTEAN® TGX™ Precast Gel with 10% acrylamide/bis-acrylamide concentration (Bio-Rad) and subjected to electrophoresis at 150 V for 45-60 min to separate the proteins based on their molecular weight.

After electrophoresis, the separated proteins were transferred to a 0.2 μm PVDF membrane using the Trans-Blot Turbo transfer system (Bio-Rad) according to the mixed molecular weight protocol. The membranes were blocked in a solution of tris-buffered saline containing 0.1% Tween-20 (TBS-T) and 5% milk for 90 min at room temperature to prevent non-specific binding. Following blocking, the membranes were incubated with the primary antibody overnight at 4°C.

The next day, the membranes were washed three times with TBS and then incubated with the appropriate secondary antibody in TBS-T 5% milk for 1 h at room temperature. After a further three washes in TBS-T, the protein bands were visualized using the Clarity Western ECL substrate (Thermo Fisher Scientific) and detected using the ChemiDoc system (Bio-Rad).

To assess multiple proteins on the same membrane, the membranes were stripped using Restore™ PLUS Western Blot Stripping Buffer (Thermo Fisher Scientific) according to the manufacturer’s instructions. This process involved incubating the membranes in a stripping buffer for 15 min, followed by three washes with 1X TBS. The membranes were then re-blocked and re-probed with different primary and secondary antibodies. This stripping and re-probing process was repeated up to three times.

sec.title: Transwell assay
sec.p: RPE1 cells were cultured in T75 flasks and serum-depleted for 48 h once they reached 70-80% confluency. Cell Culture Inserts for 24 Well Carrier Plate System with 8 µm pore were placed in a 24-well plate, and test media was added to the outer compartment of each well. Test media could be DMEM 10% FBS, DMEM supplemented with 2 ng/ml TGF-β, DMEM supplemented with 2 ng/ml EGF, or DMEM alone. Then, cells were detached with 100 μL/cm2 TrypLE™ Express (Gibco), which was neutralized by adding the same amount of serum-depleted media and gently shaking the culture vessel for 30 seconds. Cells were seeded in the inner compartment of each well with a density of 5 x 104 cells/well. The 24-well plate was in a humidified incubator (37 °C, 5% CO2) for 6 h, after that, inserts were discarded. Then, migrated cells were washed with PBS and fixated with ice-cold methanol for 20 mins. The plate was let dry for 30 mins after removing the methanol and incubated overnight at 4 °C. Next day, cells were stained with Crystal Violet (Merck) for 20 mins. After washing the cells three times with distilled water, cells were lysed with 10% acetic acid and the absorbance was measured in a microplate reader (BioRad) at a wavelength of 595 nm.

sec.title: Antibodies
sec.p: Antibodies were used for either Western blotting (WB) or immunofluorescence microscopy assay (IFM) as indicated in Supplementary Table 3. Secondary antibodies were used at 1:600 for IFM protocol or at 1:3000 for WB. They are also present in the specific part of the STAR Methods table.

sec.title: Data acquisition and statistical analysis
sec.p: Quantification of fluorescence or WB band intensity was achieved using Fiji-ImageJ software (J et al., 2012).

Data visualization and statistical analysis were performed with the software GraphPad Prism 8.00. Differences among groups were compared using two-way ANOVA followed by Holms-Sidak correction, or Student’s t-test (two-tailed, unpaired) when there were only two groups. The differences were considered significant when *p < 0.05, **p < 0.01, ***p < 0.001 and ****p < 0.0001.

sec.title: Materials availability
sec.p: The materials used and generated in this study (i.e. plasmids, cell lines, etc.) are available from the lead contact. Further information and requests for resources and additional data should be directed to and will be fulfilled by the lead contact, Diana Valverde (dianaval@uvigo.gal).

sec.title: Disruption of BBSome subunits cause ciliary shortening and decreased number of cilia
sec.p: To study the role of the BBSome in endocytosis we generated human retinal epithelium (RPE1) cell lines deficient in the BBS1 or BBS4 genes. BBS1 was selected because it is the most frequently altered gene in the affected BBS population worldwide (the p.M390R mutation is present in 28% of patients). On the other hand, BBS4 is an external BBSome subunit that presumably interacts with many proteins involved in protein degradation, a crucial pathway in RPE1 cells for recycling photoreceptors. Furthermore, both subunits are crucial for correctly assembling and translocating the BBSome to the ciliary base (Prasai et al., 2020). To this end, we generated three knockout (KO) clones each harbouring a deletion of either BBS1 or BBS4 using the CRISPR-Cas9 gene editing technique (Suppl. Fig. 1). Of the three clones generated for each KO, only clone 3 of the BBS4 KO appears to have failed. As a result, only clones 1 and 2 from each KO cell line were selected for further experimentation.

We conducted a series of experiments to confirm that our cell lines replicated the pathological phenotype described in the literature. First, we performed immunofluorescence microscopy (IFM) to determine the number and length of cilia in the preparation. It is well-documented that animal models deficient for BBS1 have a similar number of cilia to wild-type (WT) models, but they are significantly shorter (Castro-Sánchez et al., 2019; Xie et al., 2021). However, there is limited data on BBS4 deficiency.

We labelled ARL13B with Alexa Fluor 488 and acetylated tubulin with Alexa Fluor 594, both recognized cilia markers and evaluated the number and length of cilia present in the cells (Figure 1 A). As expected, BBS1-deficient cells exhibited shorter cilia; in the BBS4-deficient cell line, the cilia were not only shorter compared to control cells but were also less frequent (Figure 1 B). It is known that BBS1 deficiency produces a milder pathological phenotype compared to deficiencies in other BBSome subunits (Castro-Sánchez et al., 2015; Niederlova et al., 2019).

Next, we evaluated the different phases of the cell cycle in serum-supplemented media (Figure 1 C). After 24 h of incubation, BBS1 or BBS4 KO cells show no significant differences compared with the WT. Then we performed an apoptosis assay to test whether how the loss of ciliary length could be affecting cell survival. (Figure 1 D). The BBS1 and BBS4 knockout (KO) cells had lower early apoptotic populations (3.8% and 3.6%, respectively) compared to wild-type (WT) cells (6.5%) when grown in serum-supplemented media. However, in serum-depleted media, which promotes cilia formation, only BBS4 KO cells showed a significant change in early apoptosis (Figure 1 C, D). These results suggest a slight resistance to apoptosis in these KO cells and a differential response linked to ciliary formation.
These findings highlight that BBS1 and BBS4 deficiencies impact ciliary structure and cell survival, contributing to the understanding of their roles in ciliopathies.

sec.title: Serum Depletion-Induced Differential Colocalization of BBS1 and BBS4 with Endocytic Vesicles at the Ciliary Pocket
sec.p: After confirming our KO cell lines replicated the pathological phenotype described in the literature, we tested the implication of silencing the two BBS subunits in the endocytic process of the CiPo. To this end, we conducted a series of IFM experiments in RPE1 WT cells, assessing the colocalization (represented by the Pearson correlation coefficient, PCC) of BBS1 and BBS4 with endosomal trafficking markers (Suppl. Fig. 2) such as EEA1 (early endosomes), RAB11 (recycling endosomes), RAB7 (late endosomes), and LAMP2 (lysosomes).

Most adult cells have exited the cell cycle and remain in a non-dividing, quiescent state. However, much of our knowledge about endocytosis comes from studies conducted in proliferating cells. This raised the question of whether BBSome-mediated endocytic dynamics differ between quiescent cells and those actively progressing through the cell cycle. Understanding these differences could reveal important insights into how cellular processes are regulated under different physiological states. The IFM analysis of RPE1 cells revealed that under serum-depleted conditions, i.e. quiescent cells, the colocalization of BBS1 with various vesicles in the endocytic pathway decreased compared to cells in full-growth media. Among the vesicles examined, BBS1 showed the highest colocalization with RAB11. This suggests that BBS1 is more closely associated with recycling endosomes (RAB11) in both culture media. In contrast, BBS4 exhibited a significant increase in colocalisation only with RAB7 under serum-supplemented media, indicating a stronger interaction with late endosomes. Notably, the interaction between BBS4 and all vesicles barely changes under serum-depleted conditions.

sec.title: Loss of BBS proteins results in an accumulation of proteins related to the TGF-β pathway and EMT
sec.p: After confirming the BBSome’s association with the endocytic compartment, we sought to identify the main receptors affected by BBS1 and BBS4 deficiencies in RPE1 cells, in addition to known receptors like Notch, insulin, and leptin. During mitosis, the process of endosomal trafficking decreases, but CME is responsible for internalizing specific receptors, such as those for TGF-β, fibroblast growth factor (FGFR), the Notch receptor, and components of the planar cell polarity (PCP) complex (Celsr1, Frizzled 6, Vangl2), as shown in fly models (Bökel et al., 2006; Coumailleau et al., 2009; Devenport et al., 2011; Cota and Davidson, 2015; Heck and Devenport, 2017). The function of this selective receptor endocytosis is to ensure equal or asymmetric partitioning of these receptors between the daughter cells during mitosis.

To accomplish this, we performed a proteomic analysis focused exclusively on cell surface proteins. As the aim was to determine the largest number of receptors that could be affected by an inefficient function of the BBSome, these experiments were carried out in serum-supplemented media, i.e., under cycling conditions. We seeded three replicates of each of the three clones for BBS1 KO, BBS4 KO, and WT. The surface proteins were labelled with biotin and isolated via streptavidin pulldown.

The proteomic analysis revealed that BBS1 KO cells exhibited an accumulation of proteins associated with all the previously described pathways (FZD6, FGFR, TGFBR1) and more internalization of DPP4 (Figure 2 A). Inhibition of the internalization process of these receptors can disrupt the partitioning among the daughter cells and compromise tissue polarity (Bökel et al., 2006; Heck and Devenport, 2017), which seems to be the case in BBS1 KO cells. One of the main characteristics of ciliopathies is losing cell polarity (D et al., 2011; Hl et al., 2016; Wang et al., 2021).

Also, key proteins of EMT and the TGF-β pathway (Figure 2 A) are accumulated, including endoglin (ENG), crystallin-α B (CRYAB), and actin alpha 2 (ACTA2), suggesting that these pathways are dysregulated in the absence of BBS1. Gene Ontology (GO) analysis of altered protein receptors further indicated disruptions in endocytosis, transmembrane receptor protein kinase activity, and TGF-β receptor activity. (Figure 2)

To verify that the enrichment of proteins related to the TGF-β pathway was a result of the pathological phenotype associated with the KO lines, we performed qPCR to measure the expression levels of the TGFBR1 and IFT88, a protein that is part of the IFT-B complex, which is required for ciliary assembly and maintenance. Neither gene was overexpressed in any of the KO cells compared to the WT (Suppl. Fig. 3), indicating that the accumulation of proteins in the membranes of the KO cell lines is due to an alteration in the BBSome. Neither of these two proteins is detected in the total differentially expressed proteome when comparing between KO and WT cells (data not shown).

sec.title: Differential Endocytic Trafficking of TGFBR1 and Transferrin Highlights BBSome’s Role in Ciliary and Non-Ciliary Pathways in Quiescent Cells
sec.p: To investigate possible alterations in the endocytic process of TGFBR1 in KO cell lines, we performed colocalization experiments with various endosomal markers (Figure 3). These experiments were compared with the dynamics of transferrin, a well-characterised marker of endocytic recycling (Suppl. Fig. 4), to study the endocytic dynamics of a specific receptor and link it to ciliary function. The experiments were carried out in a serum-depleted medium for 48 h, followed by stimulation at the indicated times. Mechanisms of endocytosis in quiescent cells are not fully understood but are believed to be essential for key cellular functions, such as primary cilia formation, cell polarisation, and regulation of cell-cell junctions (Lin et al., 2015; Goto et al., 2017), all of which are related to our findings on the proteome.

Our analysis revealed significant differences between WT and BBS1/BBS4 KO cells regarding the colocalization of TGFBR1 and transferrin (Tnf-555) with markers such as EEA1, RAB7, RAB11 and LAMP2 at different time points. In the case of transferrin (Suppl. Fig. 4), which recycles through RAB11, both KO lines showed reduced colocalization with EEA1 at 5 min of Tnf-555 labelling, with BBS4 KO exhibiting even lower levels of colocalization. Colocalization with RAB11 was reduced at all time points in both KO cells, although BBS4 KO showed a gradual increase over time. In contrast, colocalization with RAB7 decreased over time in WT cells but increased in BBS4 KO cells, particularly at earlier time points. This suggests that WT cells efficiently internalise, degrade, and recycle transferrin to the plasma membrane after 15 min, while BBS1 KO cells show a 5-min delay in internalisation, followed by predominant degradation. On the other hand, exhibit minimal changes in internalisation over time, indicating a poor response to receptor stimulation.

For TGFBR1 (Figure 3), both BBS1 and BBS4 KO cells showed increased colocalization with EEA1 and RAB11 at 30 min, with BBS1 KO showing higher levels. Colocalization with RAB7 varied: it was lower in BBS1 KO at 10 min but increased in BBS4 KO at 60 min. Both KO cells also exhibited increased colocalization with LAMP2 at 10 and 30 min. At 60 min, BBS4 KO had higher colocalization with LAMP2, while BBS1 KO showed less. In WT cells, TGFBR1 colocalization peaked at 60 min for EEA1, RAB7, and LAMP2, with RAB11 peaking earlier, at 10 min. These observations suggest that in WT cells, TGFBR1 undergoes efficient trafficking through endocytic compartments, balancing recycling and degradation. On the contrary, KO lines exhibit distinct peaks in the recycling and degradative pathways, with the degradative pathway becoming more prominent over time, particularly in BBS4 KO cells. Both processes present a more sustained receptor internalization over time, which could indicate a greater activation of the TGF-β pathway, especially in the case of BBS1 KO, which also recycles the receptor more.

The differences in TGFBR1 localisation between KO lines align with the specific vesicles with which each KO line’s depleted BBSome subunit interacts most. In BBS1 KO cells, TGFBR1 accumulates primarily in recycling vesicles, whereas in BBS4 KO cells, it is found predominantly in late endosomes. These shifts suggest that the loss of BBS proteins disrupts normal endocytic and recycling processes. When comparing transferrin and TGFBR1, differences were observed even in WT cells, indicating that ciliary and nonciliary endocytosis have distinct dynamics. Although TGFBR1 in WT cells maintains a balance between recycling and degradation via the lysosomal pathway, the transferrin receptor is predominantly recycled. However, in BBS1 KO cells, this balance shifts: most TGFBR1 is recycled, but there is a 5-min delay in its internalisation. As a result, the receptor is presumably degraded and cannot efficiently return to the membrane. On the contrary, BBS4 KO cells exhibit a predominance of TGFBR1 degradation, with little to no response in transferrin receptor recycling, indicating a disruption in normal receptor trafficking processes. The altered endocytic processes in KO cells further suggest that BBSome is involved in both types of endocytosis.

sec.title: Autophagy degradation of the TGFBR1 receptor is not impaired with the loss of BBS proteins
sec.p: TGFBRs can be degraded via ubiquitination or through the lysosomal pathway, depending on the proteins involved (Lönn et al., 2009; Huang and Chen, 2012). SMAD7, for example, binds to SMURF2 to form an E3 ubiquitin ligase that targets TGFBR1 for degradation (Kavsak et al., 2000). However, in BBS4 KO cells, TGFBR1 primarily follows the degradative pathway, with significantly higher accumulation in lysosomes compared to other cell lines (Figure 3). This prompted us to examine the state of autophagy, as it plays a critical role in RPE1 cells by recycling defective photoreceptor components. Given this, we explored whether there was a shift toward autophagic degradation.

Despite elevated TGFBR1 levels in lysosomes, overall receptor degradation remained stable over time, and no significant differences were found in autophagy markers such as p62 and LC3B between KO and WT cells (Suppl. Fig. 5 B). These findings were held under both serum-depleted and normal conditions. Western blot analysis of TGFBR1 and autophagy markers during TGF-β stimulation revealed differences only in the negative control using Bafilomycin A1 (BafA1), an autophagosome inhibitor. This suggests that TGFBR1 degradation may occur via non-autophagic pathways, such as direct lysosomal degradation following endocytosis, or proteasome degradation. However, proteins directly related to autophagy could be promoting non-degradative pathways. This is the case of Beclin-1, which is required for the recycling of TGFBR1, facilitating its localization to RAB11+ endosomes (O’Brien et al., 2015).

sec.title: Loss of BBS proteins enhances cell migration and EMT
sec.p: After identifying alterations in TGFBR1 in KO cell lines, we explored the potential metabolic implications, particularly focussing on the EMT process. Quiescent cells, such as endothelial cells, are often integrated into tissues and form cell-cell junctions on their basolateral membranes, making EMT critical for retinal epithelial cells and relevant for BBS pathology. To assess EMT, we analysed various markers using qPCR.

Under normal culture conditions, BBS1 KO cells already showed a mesenchymal predisposition, with significant activation of EMT markers (Suppl. Fig. 6 A) such as CDH2 and downregulation of markers such as CDH1. The results on SNAI1 and SNAI2 or TWIST1 transcription factors that activate EMT processes contrast, and in BBS1 KO they are not active or even appear repressed, even under stimulation with TGF-β. On the contrary, BBS4 KO cells showed a more epithelial phenotype, with reduced expression of CDH2, ACTA2, and CRYAB. However, after 48 h of serum depletion and 30 min of TGF-β stimulation, the EMT activity increased. BBS1 KO cells exhibited a slight but significant increase in ACTA2 and CRYAB expression, along with a notable decrease in CDH1 expression. BBS4 KO cells also showed decreased CDH1 levels, but increased expression of CDH2, VIM, and SNAI1. CTNNB1 expression increases significantly in both cell lines after stimulation.

To further investigate the implications of EMT, we performed a wound-healing assay to evaluate cell proliferation (Suppl. Fig. 6 B). Cells were serum depleted for 48 h, then stimulated with different cytokines, and images were taken at 6- and 24-h post-wounding. Endothelial growth factor (EGF) was used as a positive control and serum-depleted medium as a negative control. Both the BBS1 KO and BBS4 KO lines showed slower wound closure compared to WT, suggesting a partial EMT process in which migration and loss of polarity are more prominent than cell proliferation.

Following confirmation of differential EMT marker and no increased proliferation in KO cells after stimulation with TGF-β and EGF stimulation, we assessed the role of the TGF-β pathway in EMT. This included a transwell assay using the same cytokines as the wound healing assay and IFM of EMT markers such as ACTA2 and N-cadherin (Figure 4).

IFM revealed higher levels of ACTA2 and N-cadherin in KO cells, both under basal conditions and after 6 h of TGF-β stimulation (Figure 4 A). ACTA2 showed particular significance: In BBS1 KO cells, filament formation was detected even at time 0 h, confirming a stronger mesenchymal phenotype without stimulation. However, in BBS4 KO cells, filaments were absent at 0 h, and ACTA2 was concentrated in a crescent shape around the nucleus, forming filaments only after stimulation but maintaining perinuclear accumulations.

In the transwell experiment (Figure 4 B), both KO lines showed significantly higher migration capacity than WT under the same conditions used in the wound healing assay. BBS1 KO cells nearly doubled their migratory capacity compared to WT, while BBS4 KO cells also showed increased migration, although to a lesser extent. Despite altered EMT and reduced proliferative capacity, BBS1 KO cells demonstrated a much higher migratory and invasive capacity than WT.

To confirm the mesenchymal phenotype in KO lines, especially BBS1 KO, we performed WB analyses of EMT markers previously tested by qPCR. We also explored the activation balance between the canonical and noncanonical TGF-β pathways by analyzing key kinases involved in these pathways (Figure 5). We analysed their expression at baseline and after 30 min of stimulation, the maximum activity time of the TGF-β pathway, to check if the answer was quick (Figure 5 A). Both KO lines exhibited a predisposition toward an EMT phenotype, which was confirmed by qPCR and WB for the N-cadherin and β-catenin markers, where higher expression was observed at time 0 min in KO cells, followed by a decrease at 30 min compared to WT. SNAIL and SLUG levels, although not significant, are higher in both KO cell lines at time 0, remain at t 30 min or decrease slightly, while they increase in WT cells. This is in line with what was postulated for N-cadherin levels: KO cells start from a more mesenchymal stage and the pathway is saturated earlier than in WT cells. Although ACTA 2 baseline levels were consistent with qPCR and IFM data, at 30 min, WB showed a decrease that did not align with the qPCR results. IFM at 6 h revealed the highest filament formation in KO cells, suggesting that ACTA2 may have a slower response than other markers. VIM also showed a significant reduction at 30 min, indicating variability in marker response times. However, the most interesting case worth highlighting is that of CRYAB, perfectly in line with the results on gene expression, where it is not detected at all for BBS4 KO but appears to accumulate significantly in BBS1 KO after stimulation. Studies found that αβ-crystallin was found to modulate EMT through SNAIL and SLUG, acting as a molecular chaperone for SMAD4 (Ishikawa et al., 2016).

The ciliary TGF-β signalling pathway involves receptor recruitment to the primary cilium, which facilitates the activation of receptor-SMAD (R-SMAD) transcription factors (SMAD2/3). This process depends on the internalization of active receptors through CME in the CiPo. Activated R-SMADs form a complex with co-SMAD (SMAD4), which translocates to the nucleus to drive gene expression.

To assess the balance between canonical and non-canonical TGF-β pathways, we performed WB analyses of key kinases, measuring SMAD2 and ERK1/2 phosphorylation at various time points after TGF-β stimulation in quiescent cells (Figure 5 B). Phosphorylation levels were normalised to WT, and fold change was calculated. At 30 min, we observed increased phosphorylation of SMAD2/3, indicating greater stimulation of the canonical TGF-β pathway in KO cells, particularly in BBS1 KO, in conjunction with reduced phosphorylation of the non-canonical ERK1/2 pathway in BBS4 KO cells. Enhanced pathway activation was already evident before peak, consistent with previous findings that KO cells exhibit more mesenchymal traits even without stimulation.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: Our study aimed to explore the role of BBS1 and BBS4 KO retinal cells using plasma membrane proteomics to better understand the molecular mechanisms of BBS, particularly in receptor endocytosis. Retinal degeneration affects nearly 100% of people with BBS, characterized by early loss of photoreceptors, night blindness, and progressive visual decline leading to blindness (Denniston et al., 2014; Weihbrecht et al., 2017). Mouse models show that despite photoreceptor degeneration, some functionality remains, which highlights the importance of understanding the tissue-specific regulation of BBSome entry into cilia (Hsu et al., 2021).

Given the importance of RPE integrity for photoreceptor health, we used hTERT-RPE1 cells to model the KO phenotypes of BBS1 and BBS4. Both KO lines showed shorter cilia, but with different ciliation frequencies: BBS1 KO cells retained normal ciliation rates with shorter cilia, while BBS4 KO cells showed fewer cilia. This suggests distinct roles for BBS1 and BBS4, consistent with their roles in pre-BBSome nucleation and BBSome assembly (Prasai et al., 2020). BBS4 helps nucleate the pre-BBSome in the pericentriolar satellites, while BBS1 mediates its transport to the ciliary base, showing that both are essential for proper BBSome function in the primary cilia.

Ciliary dysfunction is associated with impaired endocytosis. The BBSome seems essential for correctly internalising receptors at the CiPo and recycling back to the plasma membrane, at least in invertebrates, where cilia-independent functions are already described: T. brucei BBS proteins form a BBSome that interacts with clathrin and is located on the membranes of the flagellar pocket and nearby cytoplasmic vesicles (Langousis et al., 2016), and in the C. elegans photoreceptor protein LITE-1 stability in ciliated ASH photosensory neurones is regulated by BBSome through Rab5-mediated endocytosis (Zhang et al., 2022). Several signalling pathways are involved in RPE differentiation, including ciliary pathways such as Sonic hedgehog (Shh), Wnt/β-catenin, Notch, and TGF-β (Perron et al., 2003; Burke, 2008; Schouwey et al., 2011). Studies in zebrafish and human cells have shown that BBSome plays a crucial role in internalising receptors, such as leptin and insulin receptors, and recycling them to the plasma membrane (Seo et al., 2009; Guo et al., 2016; Starks et al., 2015). Mislocalization and impaired trafficking of these receptors, particularly leptin and insulin receptors, contribute to the metabolic dysfunctions seen in BBS, such as hyperphagia and obesity (Haws et al., 2021).

Endocytosis regulates receptor availability on the cell surface, with continuous internalisation preventing excessive signalling and cell cycle reentry (Koo et al., 2012). This regulation is essential for the TGF-β pathway, where normal cells degrade internalised TGFBR1 to limit signalling and prevent EMT. However, in KO cells, TGFBR1 is recycled instead of degraded, which could predispose cells to EMT through sustained signalling. In BBS4 KO cells, receptor degradation is increased, potentially reducing EMT predisposition compared to BBS1 KO cells. TGFBR1 is expressed in fewer cell types compared to TGFBR2 (TGFBR1: https://www.proteinatlas.org/ENSG00000106799-TGFBR1/tissue+cell+type; TGFBR2: https://www.proteinatlas.org/ENSG00000163513-TGFBR2/tissue+cell+type; data available from v109.proteinatlas.org) (Uhlén et al., 2015; Sjöstedt et al., 2020), making TGFBR1 the limiting factor for receptor activation and signalling initiation.

Our proteomic analysis found a significant enrichment of TGFBR1 on the plasma membrane of BBS KO cells, which influences EMT through R-SMAD signalling, which depends on CME. Our findings on altered endocytosis in KO cells suggest that BBSome function differs between receptor types, playing a key role in the coordination of cilia-dependent and cilia-independent endocytic pathways. TGF-β signalling, closely linked to receptor internalisation, requires CME for proper activation (Balogh et al., 2013; Ehrlich, 2016; Pedersen et al., 2016). Upon ligand binding, TGFBR1 is internalized via the ciliary pocket and interacts with early endosomes to enhance signalling. The fate is then determined: RAB7 promotes degradation through late endosomes, while RAB11 supports recycling (Vander Ark et al., 2018).

In BBS1 KO cells, we observed an increase in TGFBR1 accumulation in recycling endosomes, compared to previous studies that showed receptor accumulation in late endosomes with reduced recycling (Leitch et al., 2014). This difference could be due to methodological variations since we used RPE1 KO cells while Leitch et al. used siRNA knockdown cells. The distribution during asymmetric cell division may also play a role in these differences since endosomes containing receptors such as Notch are targeted to one daughter cell during mitosis to regulate cell fate (Coumailleau et al., 2009; Cota and Davidson, 2015; Derivery et al., 2015).

In BBS1 KO cells, markers (e.g., E-cadherin, N-cadherin, VIM, SNAIL, ACTA2) showed a more mesenchymal profile, correlating with increased migration under TGF-β stimulation. This supports the hypothesis that BBSome dysfunction alters receptor trafficking and EMT through R-SMAD signalling, overstimulating the TGF-β pathway. The mislocalization of receptors, as seen with PDGFRa in IFT20-deficient cells, has been associated with excessive signalling (Schmid et al., 2018).

These findings align with previous studies (Freke et al., 2023) showing the involvement in EMT across different tissues. This study expands the understanding of the role of BBS1 in the regulation of RPE-specific EMT via the TGF-β pathway. Although both BBS1 and BBS4 KO cells exhibited altered EMT, BBS1 deficiency led to a more pronounced mesenchymal phenotype and increased migration, potentially disrupting the epithelial barrier vital for photoreceptor support. This contrasts with previous reports suggesting that BBS1 deficiency leads to milder phenotypes (Castro-Sánchez et al., 2015; Niederlova et al., 2019). Given that the p.M390R mutation in BBS1 is the most common BBS mutation, our results in RPE1 cells could have significant implications for many patients with BBS, particularly concerning gene therapy targeting retinal degeneration. Disruption in the structure and polarity could hinder the effectiveness of gene therapies by compromising the blood-retinal barrier and viral delivery to photoreceptors.

We propose a model to explain the role of coordinating cilia-dependent and independent receptor trafficking (Figure 6). In cells cycling without primary cilia, normal cells balance TGFBR1 recycling and degradation to prevent excessive signalling and control EMT. In BBS1 KO cycling cells, the accumulation on the membrane and reduced endocytosis lead to uneven receptor distribution and altered polarity, promoting uncontrolled proliferation and EMT. In BBS4 KO cells, receptor trafficking remains balanced between recycling and degradation, limiting EMT activation. In quiescent cells with primary cilia, normal cells use the ciliary pocket for controlled internalisation of TGFBR1, ensuring balanced TGF-β signalling. However, in BBS1 KO quiescent cells, defective primary cilia cause prolonged receptor recycling, leading to hyperactivated TGF-β signalling and increased EMT. BBS4 KO cells, while also defective in the cilia, show increased receptor degradation, limiting TGF-β signalling and EMT.

However, our study has limitations, including the exclusive use of cell lines that may not fully replicate animal models or patient cells, although other studies support our results. Identification of the role in EMT processes across various cell types suggests new therapeutic strategies to slow tissue deterioration.

In conclusion, we demonstrate that BBSome, particularly BBS1, is a key regulator of receptor endocytosis and signalling, with implications for EMT. BBS1 deficiency leads to more severe EMT alterations in RPE1 cells. The enrichment of TGFBR1 in the plasma membrane and altered trafficking highlight the broader impact of BBSome dysfunction on the dynamics of the receptor. These findings improve our understanding of BBS pathology and suggest that targeting the TGF-β pathway may offer new therapeutic approaches for retinal degeneration and other complications of BBS. Future research should explore the combination of gene therapy with EMT inhibitors to improve treatment outcomes in BBS patients.

list-item.p: Depletion of BBS1 and BBS4 alters endocytic trafficking as well as length and/or frequency of primary cilia, affecting the internalisation of receptors at the ciliary pocket.
BBS1 knockout cells show increased EMT, up-regulation of mesenchymal markers, enhanced migration, and reduced proliferation after TGF-β stimulation.

BBS1 knockout cells exhibit increased TGFBR1 recycling, while BBS4 KO cells exhibit balanced receptor degradation and recycling, indicating distinct roles of these two BBSome components in receptor trafficking.
Targeting the TGF-β pathway and EMT may provide therapeutic options for retinal degeneration in Bardet-Biedl syndrome.

caption.title: Graphical abstract exemplifying endocytic dynamics in cycling and quiescent cells with different dysfunctional BBSome subunits.
caption.p: In cells cycling without primary cilia, normal cells maintain a balance between TGFBR1 recycling and degradation, preventing excessive signalling and controlling EMT. In BBS1 KO cycling cells, the accumulation on the membrane and reduced endocytosis disrupt this balance, causing uneven receptor distribution and altered cell polarity, which promotes uncontrolled proliferation and EMT. On the contrary, BBS4 KO cells preserve a balance in receptor trafficking between recycling and degradation, thereby limiting EMT activation. In quiescent cells with primary cilia, normal cells use the ciliary pocket to regulate TGFBR1 internalisation, ensuring balanced TGF-β signalling. However, in KO quiescent cells, defective primary cilia lead to prolonged receptor recycling, resulting in hyperactivated TGF-β signalling and increased EMT. BBS4 KO cells, despite having ciliary defects, exhibit increased receptor degradation, curbing TGF-β signalling and EMT.
